description.narrative:
Det långa inbördeskriget i Somalia har resulterat i stora flyktingströmmar där somalier har spritts över världen, vilket har medfört en "brain drain" av Somalia. Den stora somaliska diasporan har även skaffat sig erfarenheter och utbildning i de länder de har flyttat till. Den somaliska diasporan har dessutom ett mycket aktivt föreningsliv, stora remitteringar till Somalia och följer den politiska utvecklingen i sitt forna hemland mycket noga. Detta reflekteras även i Resultatstrategin för Sveriges internationella bistånd till Somalia 2013-2017, då diasporans bidrag till utvecklingen i Somalia skall stödjas. Forum Syds diasporaprogram i Somalia 2015-2017 bidrar till att komplettera de finansiella remitteringarna med sociala remitteringar för att stärka marginaliserade grupper och stärka det svaga civilsamhället i Somalia. Det kompletterar även andra utvecklingsinsatser genom internationella organisationer och FN och bidrar mer direkt till att bygga somalisk kapacitet för att hantera Somalias utvecklingshinder. Dessutom kompletterar programmet Sidas stöd för diaspora experter att återvända och arbeta för ministerier i Somalia vilket implementeras av IOM samt ett planerat stöd inriktat på den privata sektorn.
Det stora engagemanget från den somaliska diasporan är grunden för Forum Syds program, vilket bygger vidare på en pilotfas som har genomförts 2012-2014 med stöd från Sida. Det föreslagna programmet utökar och fördjupar programmet jämfört med pilotfasen och det syftet är att diasporan skall bidra till att "Marginaliserade grupper, framförallt kvinnor och ungdomar (rättighetsinnehavare) och civilsamhällesorganisationer har ökat deltagande i beslutsprocesser i Somalia". Det övergripande målet är sedan nedbruten i delmål vilka inkluderar fokus på demokrati och mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet, hållbar försörjning, regionala initiativ (för att öka kontakten mellan olika regioner i Somalia, främst med fokus på civilsamhället) och kapacitetsbyggande.
Detta program fortsätter och utökar den vidareförmedling av medel till diaspora organisationer för projekt i Somalia tillsammans med lokala partners som har använts under pilotfasen 2012-2014. Men programmet utökas även med ett "regionalt initiativ" vilket syftar till att överbrygga den fragmentering av Somalia som inbördeskriget har skapat genom att engagera civilsamhället i olika delar av landet för att återuppbygga förtroendet mellan olika grupper. Programmet kommer även att stödja lokala partners direkt med kapacitetsbyggnad eftersom diasporaorganisationerna inte alltid har den kapacitet som krävs för att göra detta samt för att möjliggöra för fler organisationer att delta i programmet. Insatsen sträcker sig över tre år, 2015-2017, och Forum Syd avser att öppna kontor i Hargeisa samt ha representation i Galkayo och Mogadishu. Dessutom kommer stödet till diasporaorganisationerna i Sverige att skötas ifrån Stockholm.

One effect of the long civil war in Somalia is the huge flows of refugees, which has created a global Somali diaspora and a brain drain of human capital from Somalia. The diaspora have also acquired knowledge, experience and education in their new countries. The Somali diaspora have furthermore very active associations, they are sending financial remittances back and follows the political developments in Somalia carefully. The engagement is also reflected in the Results Strategy for Sweden's International Development Cooperation with Somalia 2013-2017; highlighting the diaspora involvement as a key part of the strategy. Forum Syd’s Diaspora Programme in Somalia 2015-2017 complements the financial remittances by enabling social remittances by Somali diaspora organisations to strengthen marginalised groups and the weak civil society organisations in Somalia. This programme is also complementing interventions by international organisations and the UN by directly focusing on Somali capacity to handle Somali problems. The programme is in addition to this complementing Sida’s other support focusing in the diaspora to IOM for diaspora experts to return to work in ministries in Somalia and a planned intervention focusing on the diaspora and the private sector.
The engagement of the Swedish-Somali diaspora is also the foundation of the Forum Syd's Diaspora Programme in Somalia 2015-2017. This programme will build on a pilot project by Forum Syd on the Somali diaspora, which has been running 2012-2014 with Sida funding. The suggested continuation of Forum Syd's programme will expand the scope of the programme with the main objective being; "Greater participation of marginalised people, particularly women and youth (rights holders) and civil society organisations in decision making processes, within the target areas of Somalia". Under the main objective Forum Syd will focus on five outcome areas including: democracy and human rights, gender equality, sustainable livelihoods, regional initiatives (to enhance the collaboration between different regions of Somalia, focusing on civil society) and capacity building.
This programme is expanding the sub-granting scheme to projects implemented by Somali diaspora organisations together with local partners in Somalia that was used during the pilot phase of the programme 2012-2014. In addition to this, the programme is expanded with a “regional initiative” aiming at bridging the fragmentation of the Somali society caused by the civil war through civil society engagement to build trust between different groups. The programme will furthermore support local partners in Somalia directly focusing on capacity development to enable more organisations to participate in the programme. The programme will be implemented during three years, 2015-2017 and Forum Syd will open an office in Hargeisa as well as establishing presence in Galkayo and Mogadishu. The support to the diaspora organisations in Sweden will remain under the Stockholm office.

description.narrative:
This CoP is for the period between 1st January 2018 – 31st December 2019. This since the last CoP (for handover, dated 2019-08-21) was written before the annual report was reviewed. Overall assessment of the results achieved during 2018: During 2018, Forum Syd had received 53 applications sub-grants and 23 projects were granted funding for a total of 5,861,000 SEK. In addition, 25 seed grants to Somali civil society organisations were granted during the period,for a total of 2,088,000 SEK. The seed grants supported capacity building, democracy and human rights and gender-related projects. SDP notes that the interventions supported during 2018 contributed to progress in the dialogue between rights-holders and duty-bearers in Somalia. 2018 continued to see an ongoing shift from a situation where the Somali CSOs provide basic support to local communities to be more focused on the organisations as vehicles for voicing the concerns of Somali people. One example of this is a project funded in 2018 where the main activities are to develop manuals on advocacy, leadership and campaigning to be used by rights holders and CSOs during the electoral campaigning period and overall preparing the communities for the upcoming elections in 2020. The overall quality of the submitted narrative report was poor and indicated that Forum Syd lacked capacity in both activity-planning and follow-up. There were inconsistencies in the figures, achieved results were not reported on and deviations were not justified nor communicated with Sida. Sida was especially concerned of the nature of the project (grant management) and that Forum Syd's own capacity to manage reporting and budget follow-up. Sidas assessment, after reviewing the final version of the narrative report submitted 2019-11-29, was that the expected outcomes of the programme for 2018 had been met to such an extent that the report could be approved. Overall assessment of the results achieved during 2019: During the year, Forum Syd has received 37 sub-grant proposals out of which 14 were approved, amounting to a total figure of 6 781 645 SEK. In addition, one regional initiative and 15 seed grants to Somali CSOs were supported during the period. Forum Syd had made mayor improvements when it comes to reporting and follow-up of results. According to the annual report Forum Syd has made steady progress towards its outcomes over the programme period, becoming more effective with Country Office Somalia in place and by having the sub-granting officers in Stockholm working as a team. However, two of the outcome areas are lagging behind in implementation. Forum Syd has accomplished most under Outcome 1 (Democracy and Human Rights), Outcome 2 (Gender Equality), and Outcome 5 (Developing Capacity for Partnership). Progress towards Outcome 3 (Livelihoods) has mostly been accomplished outside of the Diaspora Programme through the Swedish-Somali Business Programme. And Outcome 4 (Regional Initiatives) have been a struggle to work towards and progress has been minimal.
RESULTS PER OUTCOME AREA Outcome area 1: Democracy and Human Rights Outcome statement: "Marginalised people (right holders) and civil society organisation (CSOs) have increased their involvement and dialogue with local and federal authorities (duty bearers). They have gained greater knowledge af claiming rights and participating in the democratic processes, decision-making and accountability mechanism. Duty bearers have increased their understanding af a right-based approach." Outcome area 1 in 2018: Democracy and Human Rights - 9 sub-grants, 5 seed grants Seed grants were frequently used to support organisations in their work for democracy and human rights. Some organisations carried out activities that promoted the representation of young people in local and national policy making processes. They mobilized youth for peacebuilding to give them the capabilities and opportunities to work with local and national governments. They also implemented joint workshops, community projects or platforms that helped bridge the divide between youths and government officials. After working in the area of Human Rights and Democracy over several years, Forum Syd has funded various projects that have contributed to a movement towards change in Somalia. While it can be challenging to establish a direct link between each project and an overall outcome, Forum Syd states that projects have had an important impact on the participants while at the same time contributing to democratic changes at the political and legal levels. Outcome area 1 in 2019: 6 sub-grants, 8 seed grants During 2019, Forum Syd Somalia and its local partner organisations focused on promoting the inclusion of women, youth and other marginalized groups in the national policy making process and enacting relevant laws. This included projects to increase participation of women and youth in the upcoming election scheduled for the end of 2020 -beginning of 2021; increasing the ability of women and their groups to claim their rights; and conducting consultative meetings with both formal and informal duty bearers in order to increase their understanding of accountability. Through the seed-grant support, local CSOs also carried out activities that unified their work to push for change and meet their common goals. Women and youth have been the most prominent target groups in sub-granting projects focused on Democracy and Human Rights during 2019. Such projects have mainly worked toward increasing the participation and influence of these groups in both local and regional decision-making process but also conflict resolution. Another focus under this outcome has been projects engaging duty-bearers (e.g. traditional and religious leaders, different line ministries and the federal government) in order for them to take action against various forms of gender-based violence as well as to improve service delivery and community infrastructure, for example regarding health and water.
Outcome area 2: Gender Equality Outcome Statement: "Women and girls have increased understanding and knowledge of sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) and strengthened and participation in CSOs. Men, women, girls and boys have a greater awareness of the process that reduce sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV)." Outcome area 2 in 2018: 4 sub-grants, 3 seed grants In view of the problems faced by women in Somalia, several of Forum Syd partners like Network Against FGM/C in Somaliland, Somali Women and Children Development Association and Somali Youth Development Association, strive to continue advocating for the advancement of Somali women’s empowerment. Throughout 2018, SDP partners across Somalia continued to create positive momentum that promotes women empowerment in Somalia and Somaliland by raising awareness of gender issues such as GBV, girls’ education, lobbying for a strengthened statutory system that addresses sexual and gender-based violence, etc. Forum Syd reports that the SDP supported projects which, during 2017, laid the groundwork for two important developments that took place in Somaliland at the beginning of 2018; passing of a Rape Law and the announcing of a ‘fatwa’ in which religious scholars outlawed the use of FGM in Islam. Partners also recognize that women play a critical role in the peacebuilding process and need to be equally involved in regional initiatives and drought intervention. For instance, project partners supported the establishment of a “women’s political participation forum” in Somaliland, with the objective to provide technical and financial support to women engaged in the political process. Quite a few of the seed grants were aimed at gender equality and for the empowerment of women as well. One example is a project where women in Puntland learned about public dialogue and debate, and about the rights of women in Somalia to vote and to stand for election. They also learned about campaigning techniques, political lobbying and public speaking skills, and how to better advocate for inclusive representation of women in politics. Outcome area 2 in 2019: 4 sub-grants, 6 seed grants To address the problems faced by women in Somalia, Forum Syd supported several CSOs in all regions of Somalia who created awareness aimed at reducing all forms of violence against women and girls. Forum Syd partners such as Puntland Women Development Organisation, Ugbaad Women Association in Puntland, and Barwaaqo Voluntary Organisation in Somaliland have been at the forefront of advocacy and awareness raising. Partners have targeted leaders in the community empowering them to be agents of change at the community, district, regional and national levels and address norms that condone violence against women and girls based on religions and traditional tenets. One successful example is a project in Puntland where mosque imams have allocated a portion of their Friday summans to talk about violence against women. Projects sub-granted from the Stockholm office tend to focus on gender equality. Some of these projects often focus on democracy and human rights as well. The projects that mainly focus on outcome 2 have worked to raise awareness and strengthen community responses against child marriage and gender-based violence, most prominently FGM. Although such initiatives meet strong resistance from culture and social norms, the projects have seen progress. Involvement of local authorities and community leaders have proven successful in such cases. Projects that have a combined focus on both outcome 1 and 2 generally mobilize women, and relevant strategic actors, to strengthen their capacity and advocate for inclusion in political processes.
Outcome area 3: Sustainable Livelihoods Outcome Statement: "Increased awareness concerning sustainable livelihoods and sustainable natura/ resource management and their corresponding rights (for example: food, water, waste, energy and sanitation)." Outcome area 3 in 2018: 1 sub-grant, 1 seed grant During 2018, only two grants were approved with a focus on sustainable livelihoods, both programmes were implemented in Somaliland. The Diaspora programme has traditionally received very few applications on sustainable livelihood and it is unlikely that the objective will be met. Forum Syd’s other programme SSBP more directly addresses sustainable livelihood aspects in Somalia. Outcome area 3 in 2019: 3 sub-grants, 3 seed grants Early on, the Diaspora programme supported several vocational training projects under "livelihoods", but they had limited outcomes and therefore only very few have been approved over the past three years. During 2019, no seed-grant projects at all focused on the issue of livelihoods, but a few sub-grant projects come under this heading. There has not been any vocational-training efforts during the year. Outcome Statement: "Somali civil society organisations in the targeted regions across Somalia have increased dialogue, understanding and linkages." Outcome area 4 in 2018 After facing challenges regarding this component since the start of the programme, Forum Syd supported two organizations from different regions in Somalia (Somaliland and Puntland) to work together towards a mutual goal. The organizations were Amal Hope (SL) and the Nawaal NGO (PL). Together, they implemented a successful peacebuilding project targeting communities in the most volatile areas across the Somaliland-Puntland border. Outcome area 4 in 2019 The planned cross-regional meeting in Garowe that should have taken place late fall 2019 was put on hold awaiting approval of 2018 annual reports and disbursement of funding. Instead, CO Somalia has instead planned for two cross-regional meetings during spring 2020.
Outcome area 5: Building Capacity for Partnerships Outcome Statement: "Somali CBOs have increased their organisational capacity (processes, systems and structures)." Outcome area 5 in 2018 During the year, Forum Syd’s Country Office granted 15 different organizations seed-money, of which most of them were women and youth associations that had no formal structures, policies and systems. After being provided capacity development support from Forum Syd and partner organizations, the organizations became more capable partners with structures and systems to carry out proper advocacy work. The seed grantees were specifically chosen for their ability to reach and strengthen the capacity of otherwise hard to reach local groups. FS states that although it is still early to observe the results of these interventions, the supported CSO’s reached over 11, 000 marginalized groups in remote areas of Somaliland, Puntland and Jubaland and over 620 local and regional government officials were trained on democracy and human rights and gender equality. Outcome area 5 in 2019 While civil society has grown impressively over the past few years, according to FS many of them lack structure and procedures to operate effectively. This includes struggling to secure funding for their work. Therefore, Forum Syd supported CSOs to recruit an expert or company to provide the training to its key staff on issues such as financial management, human resources, administration, project development, fundraising, monitoring and evaluation and lobbying/advocacy skills. Twelve of the seed-grantees had a direct component in their 2019 budget for capacity development focused on activities such as updating their policies and training of staff. The other seven seed-grantees had received capacity development in previous years and used their knowledge and skills ta provide capacity development for smaller CSOs such as community-based organisations, women groups, and informal groups.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
